Definition: Salivary gland cancer is a rare type of cancer that occurs in the salivary glands.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors and exposure to radiation.
Symptoms: Lump in the jaw, pain, and difficulty swallowing.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Salivary gland stones are calcified structures that form in the salivary glands, blocking the flow of saliva.
Causes: Dehydration, reduced saliva flow, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Pain and swelling in the affected gland, especially during meals.
Treatment: Hydration, massage, and sometimes surgical removal of the stone.

Definition: Salivary gland strictures are narrowings of the ducts that carry saliva from the glands to the mouth.
Causes: Injury, inflammation, or previous surgery.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and difficulty swallowing.
Treatment: Dilation of the duct, stenting, or surgery.

Definition: Salivary gland tumors are abnormal growths that can be benign or malignant and occur in the salivary glands.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Lump in the gland, pain, and difficulty swallowing.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in various organs.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Fatigue, swollen lymph nodes, and respiratory issues.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Corticosteroids and management of symptoms.

Definition: Sarcoma is a type of cancer that arises from connective tissues, such as bone, cartilage, and muscle.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Lump or swelling, pain, and functional impairment.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by infestation with the Sarcoptes scabiei mite.
Causes: Direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person.
Symptoms: Intense itching, rash, and burrows in the skin.
Treatment: Topical scabicides and oral medications.

Definition: Schizophrenia is a chronic and severe mental disorder that affects how a person thinks, feels, and behaves.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve genetic, brain chemistry, and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized thinking.
Treatment: Antipsychotic medications and psychotherapy.

Definition: Sciatica is pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which extends from the lower back through the hips and buttocks and down each leg.
Causes: Herniated discs, spinal stenosis, and injury.
Symptoms: Pain, numbness, and weakness in the leg.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Scleroderma is an autoimmune disease that causes hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve genetic and environmental factors.
Symptoms: Skin thickening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and organ involvement.
Treatment: Management of symptoms and complications.

Definition: Scoliosis is a condition characterized by an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine.
Causes: Congenital factors, neuromuscular conditions, and idiopathic causes.
Symptoms: Uneven shoulders, back pain, and postural changes.
Treatment: Observation, bracing, and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: A seizure is a sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain that can cause changes in behavior, movements, feelings, and consciousness.
Causes: Head injury, stroke, and underlying neurological conditions.
Symptoms: Convulsions, loss of consciousness, and unusual sensations.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation, EEG, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Antiepileptic medications and management of underlying causes.

Definition: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to infection causes injury to its own tissues and organs.
Causes: Infections, particularly bacterial infections.
Symptoms: Fever, increased heart rate, and confusion.
Diagnosis: Blood tests, imaging studies, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Antibiotics, intravenous fluids, and supportive care.

Definition: Shin splints are a common exercise-related condition characterized by pain along the shin bone (tibia).
Causes: Overuse, improper footwear, and running on hard surfaces.
Symptoms: Pain along the inner part of the lower leg.
Treatment: Rest, ice, and physical therapy.

Definition: Shingles is a viral infection that causes a painful rash, caused by the varicella-zoster virus.
Causes: Reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which causes chickenpox.
Symptoms: Pain, burning, and a blistering rash.
Treatment: Antiviral medications and pain management.

Definition: Short bowel syndrome is a condition in which the body cannot absorb enough nutrients due to a lack of functional small intestine.
Causes: Surgical removal of a portion of the small intestine, congenital defects, and diseases.
Symptoms: Diarrhea, weight loss, and malnutrition.
Treatment: Nutritional support, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Shoulder pain is discomfort in the shoulder area, which can be acute or chronic.
Causes: Injuries, arthritis, and rotator cuff problems.
Symptoms: Pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion.
Treatment: Pain management, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Sialadenitis is inflammation of a salivary gland, often due to infection.
Causes: Bacterial infections, dehydration, and salivary stones.
Symptoms: Swelling, pain, and dry mouth.
Treatment: Antibiotics, hydration, and sometimes surgical intervention.

Definition: Sick sinus syndrome is a group of heart rhythm disorders due to malfunction of the sinus node.
Causes: Age-related degeneration and heart disease.
Symptoms: Palpitations, dizziness, and fainting.
Treatment: Medications and possibly a pacemaker.

Definition: Sickle cell disease is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the production of abnormal hemoglobin, leading to distorted (sickle-shaped) red blood cells.
Causes: Genetic mutation in the hemoglobin gene.
Symptoms: Anemia, pain crises, and increased risk of infections.
Treatment: Pain management, blood transfusions, and sometimes bone marrow transplant.

Definition: Silent thyroiditis is a painless inflammation of the thyroid gland that can cause temporary hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism.
Causes: Autoimmune response and hormonal changes.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight changes, and mood swings.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring thyroid hormone levels.
Treatment: Monitoring and management of symptoms.

Definition: Sinonasal mucocele is a mucus-filled cyst that occurs in the sinuses.
Causes: Obstruction of the sinus drainage pathways.
Symptoms: Facial pain, nasal obstruction, and drainage.
Treatment: Surgical drainage and management of underlying causes.

Definition: Sinus cancer refers to malignant tumors that occur in the sinuses.
Causes: Exposure to certain chemicals, smoking, and viral infections.
Symptoms: Nasal obstruction, facial pain, and bleeding.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and clinical evaluation.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Sinusitis is an inflammation of the sinuses, often due to infection.
Causes: Viral infections, bacterial infections, and allergies.
Symptoms: Facial pain, nasal congestion, and discharge.
Treatment: Nasal decongestants, saline irrigation, and antibiotics if bacterial.

Definition: Sjogren’s syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth.
Causes: Autoimmune response affecting moisture-producing glands.
Symptoms: Dryness of the eyes and mouth, fatigue, and joint pain.
Treatment: Artificial tears, saliva substitutes, and management of symptoms.

Definition: Sjogren's related salivary disease is a condition characterized by inflammation and dysfunction of the salivary glands due to Sjogren's syndrome.
Alternative Names: Salivary gland involvement in Sjogren's syndrome
Causes: Autoimmune response affecting salivary glands.
Symptoms: Dry mouth, difficulty swallowing, and increased dental caries.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and salivary gland function tests.
Treatment: Saliva substitutes, medications to stimulate saliva production, and management of symptoms.

Definition: Skin cancer is a type of cancer that forms in the skin cells.
Causes: Excessive sun exposure, tanning beds, and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Changes in skin appearance, new growths, and sores that do not heal.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and topical treatments.

Definition: Skull base tumors are abnormal growths located at the base of the skull.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Headaches, vision changes, and neurological symptoms.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Sleepwalking is a disorder that causes people to get up and walk around while in a state of sleep.
Causes: Genetics, sleep deprivation, and stress.
Symptoms: Walking or performing other complex behaviors while asleep.
Treatment: Improving sleep hygiene and addressing underlying causes.

Definition: Small cell lung cancer is a fast-growing type of lung cancer that is often associated with smoking.
Causes: Smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke.
Symptoms: Cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies, biopsy, and pulmonary function tests.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and targeted therapy.

Definition: Small intestine bacterial overgrowth is a condition where excessive bacteria grow in the small intestine.
Causes: Motility disorders, anatomical abnormalities, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
Treatment: Antibiotics, dietary changes, and management of underlying conditions.

Definition: Small intestine cancer is a rare type of cancer that occurs in the small intestine.
Causes: Genetic factors, certain inherited conditions, and chronic inflammation.
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, weight loss, and changes in bowel habits.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Soft tissue sarcoma is a type of cancer that arises from soft tissues such as fat, muscle, nerves, and blood vessels.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Lump or swelling, pain, and functional impairment.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: A sore throat is pain, scratchiness, or irritation of the throat.
Causes: Viral infections, bacterial infections, and allergies.
Symptoms: Pain, difficulty swallowing, and swollen glands.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and throat swab if bacterial infection is suspected.
Treatment: Pain relief, hydration, and antibiotics if bacterial.

Definition: Spasmodic dysphonia is a voice disorder caused by involuntary spasms of the vocal cords.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown; may involve neurological factors.
Symptoms: Voice breaks, strain, and difficulty speaking.
Treatment: Botulinum toxin injections and voice therapy.

Definition: Spasticity is a condition characterized by abnormal muscle tightness due to prolonged contraction.
Causes: Neurological conditions such as cerebral palsy and multiple sclerosis.
Symptoms: Muscle stiffness, spasms, and difficulty with movement.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Speech and language disorders are conditions that affect a person's ability to communicate effectively.
Causes: Developmental issues, neurological conditions, and hearing loss.
Symptoms: Difficulty speaking, understanding language, and forming words.
Treatment: Speech therapy and communication strategies.

Definition: Spinal cord diseases are conditions that affect the spinal cord, leading to neurological deficits.
Causes: Infections, trauma, and degenerative diseases.
Symptoms: Weakness, numbness, and loss of coordination.
Treatment: Depends on the underlying cause; may include medications and rehabilitation.

Definition: Spinal cord injury is damage to the spinal cord that results in loss of function, such as mobility or feeling.
Causes: Trauma, falls, and sports injuries.
Symptoms: Loss of movement, sensation, and reflexes.
Treatment: Emergency care, rehabilitation, and management of complications.

Definition: Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by weakness and wasting in the muscles used for movement.
Causes: Genetic mutations affecting motor neurons.
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, difficulty with movement, and respiratory issues.
Treatment: Supportive care, physical therapy, and medications.

Definition: Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal that can put pressure on the spinal cord and nerves.
Causes: Aging, arthritis, and herniated discs.
Symptoms: Pain, numbness, and weakness in the legs.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: A spinal tumor is an abnormal growth of tissue in the spinal column that can be benign or malignant.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Back pain, neurological deficits, and changes in bowel or bladder function.
Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Definition: Spondylosis is a degenerative condition of the spine that can lead to pain and stiffness.
Causes: Aging, wear and tear, and previous injuries.
Symptoms: Back pain, stiffness, and reduced range of motion.
Treatment: Pain management, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: A sprain is an injury to a ligament caused by overstretching or tearing.
Causes: Twisting or impact injuries.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and limited mobility.
Treatment: Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) and physical therapy.

Definition: Stomach cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the stomach lining.
Causes: Helicobacter pylori infection, smoking, and certain dietary factors.
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Strabismus is a condition in which the eyes do not properly align with each other when looking at an object.
Causes: Genetic factors, muscle imbalance, and neurological conditions.
Symptoms: Misalignment of the eyes, double vision, and difficulty with depth perception.
Treatment: Glasses, vision therapy, and surgery.

Definition: A strain is an injury to a muscle or tendon caused by overstretching or tearing.
Causes: Overexertion, improper lifting, and sports injuries.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and limited mobility.
Treatment: Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) and physical therapy.

Definition: Strep throat is a bacterial infection that causes inflammation and pain in the throat.
Causes: Infection with group A Streptococcus bacteria.
Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.
Treatment: Antibiotics and symptomatic relief.

Definition: Stress urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine during physical activity, coughing, or sneezing.
Causes: Weak pelvic floor muscles, pregnancy, and childbirth.
Symptoms: Urine leakage during exertion.
Treatment: Pelvic floor exercises, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: A stroke is a medical emergency that occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted.
Causes: Blood clots, hemorrhage, and atherosclerosis.
Symptoms: Sudden numbness, confusion, and difficulty speaking.
Treatment: Emergency care, medications, and rehabilitation.

Definition: A stye is a red, painful lump on the edge of the eyelid caused by an infected oil gland.
Causes: Bacterial infection, often from Staphylococcus bacteria.
Symptoms: Redness, swelling, and tenderness in the eyelid.
Treatment: Warm compresses, good hygiene, and sometimes antibiotics.

Definition: Subacute thyroiditis is an inflammation of the thyroid gland that often follows a viral infection.
Causes: Viral infections and autoimmune responses.
Symptoms: Neck pain, fever, and changes in thyroid hormone levels.
Treatment: Pain relief, anti-inflammatory medications, and monitoring.

Definition: Supraventricular tachycardia is a rapid heart rate originating above the ventricles.
Causes: Heart conditions, stress, and stimulants.
Symptoms: Palpitations, dizziness, and shortness of breath.
Treatment: Medications, vagal maneuvers, and sometimes catheter ablation.

Definition: Swallowing disorders are conditions that affect the ability to swallow normally.
Causes: Neurological conditions, structural abnormalities, and muscle disorders.
Symptoms: Difficulty swallowing, choking, and pain while swallowing.
Treatment: Swallowing therapy, dietary modifications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Swimmer's ear is an infection of the outer ear canal, often caused by water exposure.
Causes: Bacterial or fungal infections, often following water exposure.
Symptoms: Itching, redness, and pain in the ear canal.
Diagnosis: Clinical evaluation and examination of the ear.
Treatment: Ear drops, antibiotics, and keeping the ear dry.

Definition: Synovial sarcoma is a rare type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically occurs near joints.
Causes: Exact cause is often unknown; may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Lump or swelling near a joint, pain, and limited mobility.
Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy.

Definition: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.
Causes: Transmission through sexual contact.
Symptoms: Chancres, rashes, and flu-like symptoms.
Treatment: Antibiotics, typically penicillin.
